hedline.hl1: National News Briefs; Atlanta Transit Allows Ads on Abortion Rights

abstract.p: Advertisements supporting abortion rights are appearing in subway stations and bus shelters in Atlanta under agreement between transit authority and National Abortion Federation and will be last noncommercial advertisements in transit system (S)

block.p: Advertisements supporting abortion rights began appearing in subway stations and bus shelters in Atlanta this week under an agreement between the transit authority and the National Abortion Federation. But they will be the last noncommercial advertisements in the transit system.

The Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, or Marta, had rejected the advertisements last year, deeming them too controversial. The federation sued on First Amendment grounds, and a federal judge ruled against Marta in June, saying the agency's reason for rejecting the advertisements was too vague. The judge noted that Marta accepted other public-issue advertisements.

Advertisements supporting abortion rights began appearing in subway stations and bus shelters in Atlanta this week under an agreement between the transit authority and the National Abortion Federation. But they will be the last noncommercial advertisements in the transit system.

The Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, or Marta, had rejected the advertisements last year, deeming them too controversial. The federation sued on First Amendment grounds, and a federal judge ruled against Marta in June, saying the agency's reason for rejecting the advertisements was too vague. The judge noted that Marta accepted other public-issue advertisements.

On Aug. 18, Marta signed an agreement with the federation permitting the advertisements for three months. But Dee Baker, an agency spokeswoman, said Marta voted to permit only commercial advertisements after the abortion ones come down.
